snippet: Under fire for harvesting the phone calls and e-mails of millions, the Obama administration invoked Najibullah Zazi as an example of the successful use of Internet surveillance. But the claim comes with question marks.
abstract: Michael Powell Gotham column observes that Obama administration, under fire for covert surveillance of phone calls and e-mails of millions, is pointing to 2009 case of Najibullah Zazi, would-be subway bomber arrested in New York City, as justification for sweeping surveillance; holds that it is not clear in Zazi case why government tapped millions of e-mails instead of using court-approved warrants to gather intelligence.
lead_paragraph: Under fire for harvesting the phone calls and e-mails of millions, the Obama administration invoked Najibullah Zazi as an example of the successful use of Internet surveillance. But the claim comes with question marks.

headline.seo: Using a Would-Be Subway Bomber to Justify Sweeping Surveillance
headline.main: Using a Would-Be Subway Bomber to Justify Sweeping Surveillance
headline.print_headline: Using a Would-Be Subway Bomber To Justify Sweeping Surveillance
